If the patient is constricted by something violent that they cannot tolerate, and the cloth stings with a painful puncture, and we fear for the patient: then it is necessary to cut open the area and expose the fractured rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then place the instrument that preserves the surface, which was mentioned earlier: and cut the skin with ease, and proceed to do so.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two edges of the wound if it is large with stitches: and treat it with plasters until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	If a hot abscess occurs meanwhile, then hurry and infuse little pieces in rose oil, and place it on the area: and treat the patient with what is appropriate for the abscess.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	In the meantime, let them lie on their side on which they sleep, until they heal.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	¶ On the restoration of a fracture of the spine in the back and neck.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	Fractures can occur in the neck vertebrae at times, and wear (attrition) rarely affects them as well: and similarly with the spine vertebrae of the back.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	When therefore it happens to someone, and you wish to know whether it will heal or not: then consider.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	For if you see his hands already softened, and numb, and dead: and he cannot move them, nor extend them, nor contract them: and when you press them with your fingers, and prick them with a needle, he does not feel it, and does not feel pain in them: then know that it will not heal, and in most cases it is fatal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	If he can move them and feels the pressure of the fingers and the pricking: then know that the spinal bone is safe, and that the patient will be healed with treatment.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If it happens that the vertebrae of the back are affected similarly, and you wish to know whether it will heal or not: then consider his feet. If you see that they have softened, and what has happened in the hands also occurs in them: then when he lies on his back, flatulence and evacuation occur without will: and when he is laid on his belly, evacuation occurs without will: and when he lies on his back again and wishes to urinate but cannot: then know that it is fatal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Do not therefore labor in treating him.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If however nothing of that happens to him, the condition is less serious.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	And the treatment for what happens from that is to attempt to reduce the inflammation with warm applications: thus, place rubbed rose oil alone on the vertebra: or use eggs of roasted chicken.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Apply that several times a day until the warm poultice reduces the inflammation: then apply one of the binding, drying plasters to the area, and wrap it with a bandage: and instruct the patient to use rest and calm.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	Nor should he sleep upon the part with which he finds pain until it is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	If this happens during the abrasion of a sutured bone or something that has become detached from it, then it is necessary to cut above the skin and remove it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound, if it is large, with stitches.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with something flesh-forming, from ointments, until it is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	If the last bone of the tail is broken and it is the end of the tail: then it is necessary to insert the thumb into the anus and align the broken bone with the other hand as much as possible, and stabilize it in this position.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then place something on it and remove it: and treat the wound with the previous method of treatment until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	### On the Restoration of the Anus.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	The bones of the anus are rarely broken.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If they are broken, then their fracture is not complete but rather a comminution at the extremities: and they split along their length and incline inward: and the patient experiences pain in the area, and there is puncturing: and the leg that is fractured becomes numb.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And the restoration of it is such that you should extend your hand upon it, until you stand above the fracture to understand its shape.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is only at the extremities, then align that fracture as best you can according to what is prepared for you from alignment, until it resembles its natural shape.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	If there is a fracture along the length or it has already shifted inward: then have the patient lie on their belly until you prepare the restoration of that fracture.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When you have aligned it, apply a plaster over it; then place a splint made of wood or leather over it, and secure it with bandages in such a way that there is no risk of the fracture shifting or the splint moving.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And ensure that the concave area is filled so that the bandaging follows its evenness; and instruct the patient to sleep on their back or on their healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	If a hot abscess occurs, then stop the extension and restoration of it until the abscess subsides; place on it what is necessary for its settling, as previously mentioned, and then return to restoring it: and bandage it as needed.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	If there is pain or comminution in the bone, then extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	On the Restoration of Fractures: Auxiliary Methods.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	Auxiliary support is that which is between the elbow and the handle of the spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If it is fractured, then its restoration is according to one of two methods.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	One of these methods is to take a flat piece of wood of medium thickness, in the shape described below.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And two straps should be tied at both ends.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then let it be suspended from a raised place: and let the patient sit upon the seat.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	Then let him throw his broken arm over the wood until it reaches its splint, to which the curved part of the wood is attached in the middle.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then hang something heavy above it so that the attendant can pull it downward from below.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then let the physician equalize the fracture with his hands simultaneously until the bone returns to its proper position.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	And another method is to have the patient lie supine on his neck: and suspend his arm from his neck with a ligament.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Then instruct two attendants, one of whom should hold that which is above the fracture with his hands: and let the other hold below it, and let each of them pull on their respective sides.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you wish for a stronger extension, then bind below the fracture with one ligament, and above it with another ligament: and let each of the two attendants pull on their respective parts.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If the fracture is near the end of the shoulder, then it is necessary to place one ligament below the splint, and another below the fracture toward the elbow.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	And similarly if the fracture is near the elbow: then it is necessary to place a ligament above that place, and above the elbow itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then equalize the fracture with ease without labor, until the fracture is properly aligned and applied with good dressing: then bind it, if a hot abscess does not occur.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If a hot abscess occurs, then postpone the incision until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And place on it a wool cloth soaked in vinegar and rose oil until the abscess subsides; then apply compression. The method of compressing is to apply a plaster over the area.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place a bandage made of new cloth over the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then raise the arm with assistance and place the hand open on the shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And place a cloth and apply compression to the arm with assistance, so that the arm remains in place: if nothing prohibits you from doing this, and nothing changes regarding the fractured bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	But if you fear that something may change regarding the fractured bone, then use a splint: and it should be such that you place on the fracture a splint that is wider and stronger than other splints.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place the width of a finger between each splint: and the length of the splints should be according to the fracture, with an additional three fingers on all sides.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then apply compression over the splints as I described at the beginning of the chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it should be such that your compression is tighter over the location of the fracture.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And the more the fracture extends, the less should be the compression.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If you see the placement of the splints and compression as we have described, immediately when you restore the limb, then proceed: and if you fear a hot abscess, then postpone the compression and splints until the seventh day, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then examine the bandage on all three days to ensure that itching does not occur at any point, nor swelling, nor is food prevented from reaching the limb due to excessive tightness.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Therefore, correct that according to what we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	If you are confident that nothing will happen because of it, then do not remove the bandage until after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And let the patient sleep on their back, and their hands on their stomach, and place a filled mattress evenly padded with wool under them for support.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	And check at all times during the night or day to ensure that the shape of the broken limb does not change and that the bandage does not become loose.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Therefore, correct all of that with your skill.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And provide food for the patient according to the order we have provided, so that at first the food should be light and easy to digest, until their appetite begins to strengthen; then it is necessary to gradually increase the substance of their food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	It is customary for the support and leg to be bound for forty days: then it should be loosened, and a bath should be administered, and it should be treated with ointments that heal it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	If the fracture is dirty and worn, then do not remove the bandage and splint from it until fifty days have passed, and for two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	Concerning the restoration of a fractured Arm.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones, which are called the two humeri.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	One of them is small: and it is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	And the other is large, and it is that which is positioned below the small one at the lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps the larger bone is fractured alone, or the smaller one: and perhaps both are fractured simultaneously.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When the smaller bone is fractured above, then its restoration is easy, and its healing is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the bone is fractured below, the fracture is bad, and its healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	And it is worse when both bones are fractured simultaneously.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If the bone that is fractured is the smaller one above, then it is appropriate for the physician, in restoring it, to apply a small extension with ease until it is even.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If it is the larger bone that is fractured: then it is necessary to apply a much stronger binding.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	And it is necessary to place the hand in a position that facilitates its restoration, and to extend its bandaging over the pillow.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	And let the thumb of the hand be higher than all the fingers towards the upper part: and let the lower joint be higher than all the fingers or others: and the patient sitting straight should have the pillow before them, or directly in front, at a height, so that the patient does not incur labor.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then let the attendant extend the arm from the lower part, either with their hand or with a bandage.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	And another assistant extend it similarly from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the doctor should equalize the mouth until he brings it back to the best possible shape.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	If there are efforts to move in a bone fracture, then try to return all the fragments to their proper place using your strength.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	But if a detached fragment appears and pierces the skin, and you have no hope of restoring it: then cut above it, and remove it according to the method we mentioned in the preceding instructions.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	But if there is a fracture with a wound, I have already made a separate chapter for that, so take the treatment from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	If an abscess occurs at the beginning of your restoration process, then line a cloth made with cerotum from rose oil and use a white bandage that is neither too thick nor too thin. Apply the cloth on it tightly until the abscess subsides. Then remove the cerotum and apply a plaster prepared from flour powder mixed with egg whites.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then apply a splint, and let the splint placed over the fracture be somewhat wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And know that the number of splints for the arm is six in most positions: whether the fracture is in one bone or in two bones at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your bandage more firmly and forcefully over the site of the fracture, and extend it somewhat more above or below the fracture with the bandaging. Or place a softer bandage slightly less tightly, according to what was mentioned earlier at the beginning of the chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And let the cloths that wrap around the fracture be soft, moist: and not hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And let the thread with which it is bound be of linen, medium between fine and coarse, as we have described.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And examine the limb and ligament after several days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If something occurs that requires correction, such as itching in the limb: then it is necessary to wash the limb with warm water until the itching subsides, and leave the limb unbound until it calms down, then reapply the binding.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the binding has already been loosened, and the bone has moved away, and similar conditions: then correct it with your skill, and examine again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	For if nourishment is prevented from reaching the limb due to excessive binding, then it is necessary to loosen it slightly and leave it for several days until the nourishment can reach it, then bind it again.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	But if none of the issues we mentioned occur to the patient, then it is not necessary to remove the binding until after twenty days or thereabouts.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then suspend the sick person's hand to their neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	And let their neck be straight, and guard it with your skill from agitated movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	And have him sleep on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	And know that this fracture is restored in thirty days, or in thirty-two days: and it may be restored in eighteen days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All of that is according to the arrangements of temperaments, and the arrangements of virtue.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	§ On the Restoration of Fractures of the Hand.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	Know that fractures of the metacarpal bones and the joints of the fingers rarely occur.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	And it does not happen to them unless there is repeated wear and tear.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When a fracture or wear of the foot occurs, then it is necessary for the patient to sit squarely, and for there to be a seat prepared beside him at an equal distance.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place his hand upon it, extended.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then the assistant should extend the fractured bones, and the physician should adjust them until they are properly joined together.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary to apply plaster and linen, unless a hot abscess occurs.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Then place a splint on top according to the size of the area: and now wrap it in linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	但如果骨折靠近脚掌的下部，大约在脚底的位置，那么要做一个类似球形的包裹物，用布料制成：然后指示病人将受伤的脚掌紧压在其上，之后用长布条包扎固定。
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	而且要用皮革制成夹板，皮革要柔软，以便与脚掌的肌肤贴合：然后根据需要将其绑紧。
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	但如果骨折位于外侧，那么需要：在上方放置一根夹板，在下方脚掌处再放一根夹板：手应保持开放且伸直。
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Then apply compression, as the hand is turned: and extend between the fingers with a ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If it happens that one of the joints of the fingers is fractured, then if it is the thumb, it should be set as necessary.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then bind it to the sole: and if there is swelling, place a small, straight splint on it, so that the fracture can be raised and not moved.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	If the fracture is in other fingers, such as the middle, index, or ring finger, then it should be set and bound to the adjacent healthy finger. Alternatively, all of them can be bound together according to their alignment, which is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or place a small splint on it, as we said for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And consider during your restoration and after the disposal of the abscess that it has caused: and oppose with what is necessary when something happens from it, according to how its narrative continues.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	Regarding the restoration of a fractured hip.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone is often fractured and its condition becomes apparent because it turns towards the inner and posterior part.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And the restoration is done by binding one ligature above the fracture and another below the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the patient should lie face down.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then the attendant should stretch all the ligatures to the patient's affected side according to equality: and this is done when there is a fracture in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	If there is a fracture near the root of the hip bone, then the ligament should be attached to the part of the pubis, so that the extension falls upward: and another ligament below the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And similarly, if there is a fracture near the knee, then the ligament should be attached near the knee, so that the extension goes downward.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the doctor should align the bone with both hands until he restores it to its natural shape: and the bone should be joined properly.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary to apply a plaster and bandage, if an abscess does not occur in the limb.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	If an abscess occurs in it: then leave it for several days until the abscess softens and becomes warm, then return to your treatment.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	The bandaging of it should be as follows.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	You should wrap a hard bandage, that is, linen cloth, over the fracture: and fold it twice or three times: and leave some excess.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then wrap the leg until it reaches the heel at the base of the toes.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	And insert a long thread between the hip and the leg near the knee to below, and let the ends of the thread come from the upper part of two parts.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then wrap the remaining excess bandage around the leg and hip.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then place metal plates on the hip at the location of the fracture, and place one of them above the bone of the leg.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill the spaces between the thigh and the leg with soft cloths, so that the constriction may be equalized.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then begin with a strong constriction from the middle over the site of the fracture with three or four applications.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the farther you extend with the bandage from the site of the fracture, the less severe and softer should your constriction be.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then proceed to the two ends of the bandage that you have placed between the thigh and the leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Therefore, tie three splints with each of them that are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then proceed with the two ends of the bandage to the lower parts until you reach the ankle.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And with each of them, tie the ends of the splints from the other side: so that the bandage does not move from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then leave the bandage on it as long as necessary, in such a way that corrosion, abscess, swelling, and similar conditions do not occur to the limb.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	If anything should happen from that.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Hurry with the removal of it, and correct what has happened from that entirely, as we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	But if there is a fragment of bone that protrudes and causes pain: then it is necessary to even it out, if it is possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, place something over it and remove it: and treat with that which has preceded the care, until it is healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And sometimes this fracture of the hip is compressed, besides which stakes are added to it, as we said regarding assistance and the arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, when restoring such a fracture, it does not result in the patient having a limp.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if it is restored alone, besides applying the other leg to it, then it is necessary that he whose fracture this is will always limp.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And you should know that the hip is compressed for fifty days, or a few more, or a few less: all of this depends on the diversity of constitutions and other conditions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	Concerning the restoration of the fracture of the kneecap.
Caput XVI.	Chapter Sixteen.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	Know that a fracture of the kneecap rarely occurs, but wear and tear affects it very often.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	But if a fracture does occur to the kneecap, then it is either a crack or a hole in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And this can occur with an injury and without an injury.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And it is treated entirely with awareness of the sensation.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And the restoration of it is such that what has been disrupted from its parts is made equal with the fingers, until it comes together and is joined as much as possible by equality, ease, and fabrication.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then apply a plaster made from sesame flour or mill flour with egg white: and place a round stake on it if necessary: and compress it appropriately with bandages suitable for that.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the conditions we have described in other fractures: just as you would treat a hot abscess and similar conditions; so should you oppose every occurrence with what is appropriate to it until healing takes place.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	§ On the Restoration of a Fractured Leg.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	Know that the leg has two bones, one of which is thick and is called the shinbone (Cruris), and the other is slender and is called the Fibula.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	Both of these bones can be affected by fractures similar to those that affect the two bones of the arm: and for this reason, their restoration is done in a manner similar to that of the arm, and the procedure is the same.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If both bones break at the same time, the leg can be positioned in any direction due to the loss of structural integrity.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	And if the finer bone is fractured, the leg turns toward the front side.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	And if the thicker bone is fractured, you will find it below: and this is one of those that are not hidden from your observation.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then administer the extension, equalization, and binding of the bones in the same manner.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However, if the fracture of the leg is a severe one, accompanied by much bruising, the extension should be smaller and gentler due to your careful management.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	And in the treatment of the leg, there is something similar to the treatment of the arm: it is when you equalize the bones and complete all your work, then take two strips from pine wood, which are used in making window frames and should be about the width of a palm: choose those that have a moderate thickness and are not too thin: and their length should be according to the length of the leg from the knee to below.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then wrap each piece of cloth with two folds along its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And place one part of the leg from one side, and the other part from the opposite side: and they should extend from the knee to below the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then bind two bandages at three places from both extremities and the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	For when compression is prohibited, the leg turns to the right and left, and stands in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And now a cradle made of wood according to the length of the leg should be provided, and place the leg in it so that it preserves it from movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And most importantly, you should do this in a fracture when there is a wound proper with it.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then examine the leg every day and be careful to guard it with utmost diligence from abscess, swelling, or other such conditions.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If anything from those conditions occurs, then oppose it with what is necessary until it is healed, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	On the fracture of the bones of the foot and toes.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	A complete fracture of the heel does not commonly occur.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	Fractures do occur in the bones of the foot sometimes, and fractures also occasionally occur in the toes: but they rarely happen to them except as wear and tear in many circumstances.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	If a fracture occurs in the bones of the foot and you see those bones elevate themselves out of place, then the patient should place his foot on prepared ground as if walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Then stand, and place your foot on that which protrudes from those bones; afterward press it or step on it: and even it out until it returns to its proper places.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then apply a plaster and a bandage on top; and place a small board under the arch of the foot, which has two flat ends.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind it with the foot in a suitable compression after you have wrapped it with cloths and other materials it requires.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When three or four days have passed, then remove the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find the bones aligned, whether they were fractured or dislocated.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The procedure for them is as you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	If any of the fingers are fractured, then restore them and align them as I have described to you for the restoration of the fingers of the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place a splint on your finger along its length, and let it be slightly wider than the finger; then place under the foot the board I described to you, and bind it with suitable compression.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	If what is fractured among the bones is two, or three, or more, then place a splint of appropriate size wrapped in linen cloth on each finger; and bind the board below the foot: and let it rest on one end of the board outside the arch of the foot, so that it holds securely.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it is fitting for you not to forget to consider all that I have said about other fractures due to the accidents we have mentioned: and apply each remedy according to what is necessary.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	Of the fracture of a woman's vulva, and of the pubic bone, and of a man's rod.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When a woman's vulva is fractured, then have her sit in a squared position.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then tilt her to one side of her back for a little while, and support her from behind.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then the midwife should fill her vulva with a poultice until it is full, and it should form a sphere in the vulva.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then shake the woman, and gradually raise her back.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that poultice will come out until it forms a sphere in front of the vulva entrance, and the fractured part returns to its place.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a poultice on her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	When she wants to urinate, remove the poultice with ease, then allow her to urinate; and replace it as you originally inserted it: then return her to her original poultice.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Let her do this for seven days or thereabouts, for the fractured part indeed takes time to heal.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you wish, take a sheep's bladder and secure a reed tube over its opening, then insert the entire bladder into her vulva.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the tube with force until the bladder inflates inside the vulva, for the fracture will then return to its proper position.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then fill it with a poultice and have her stand for several days, as we have described, until she is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	And when the bone of the pubis of a man or woman is broken, then administer in its restoration and equalization that which we have narrated about the bone of the coccyx.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	And the truth is not concealed in these fractures that are nearby and slightly affected, especially for one who has some interest or use.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book well, for the fracture itself indicates to you in many circumstances the right way in the restoration and healing of it: therefore, understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	And when the shaft of the man's penis is broken, take the throat of a goose and insert the shaft into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place a wrap made of cloth over it and bind it up. Leave it for three days or so, and it will heal, if God wills it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	Concerning the restoration of fractures when they are accompanied by a wound.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	It is appropriate for one who has sustained a fracture accompanied by a wound, especially if it is severe, such as the hip bone or similar areas, to proceed quickly and perform phlebotomy on them immediately: if the conditions for phlebotomy are favorable, as we have mentioned.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If the wound is bleeding, then you must hurry to cut it and sprinkle powdered zegi on it: if you do not have something else at hand.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to restore the fracture on that same day: and do not postpone it unless an abscess occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If a hot abscess occurs, then postpone its restoration until the ninth day, until the abscess bursts.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach it on the third and fourth days, for you would cause it to suffer bad consequences.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	If a broken bone is prominent above the skin: then it is necessary to try to reduce and align it with your hands gently and with slight traction.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If it is not prepared for traction and alignment with your hands: then reduce it with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And the instrument is made of iron, its length being seven or eight finger widths, and its width according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And for that reason, it is necessary for the physician to take three or four of them according to the size required for it in the treatment of any type of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And let it be round: and let it have a small thickness, so that it does not double up under pressure on it during the operation: and let it have sharp ends with edges at its extremities.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And let the upper part of it be thick from the middle down to the lower parts.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	In this operation, the curved sharp end of it should be placed on the prominent end of the bone: and move it with it once, until the bone returns to some alignment.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Try therefore to align the ends of the fracture together.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If the ends of it are finely broken and do not admit a tool by proper reception, then it is necessary to cut that end of the bone until the tool has access to it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	But if you are not able to reduce them as we have described, then cut it along with one of the incisions that we mentioned: or saw it with a saw in whatever manner is possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then scrape what remains on the bone from roughness and small coatings.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	When the bone is reduced and the patient experiences severe pain after its reduction, then you know that the bone has not returned to its natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	Therefore, do it.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you provide great relief to the patient when your restoration of the bone is complete.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then dip a cloth in sharp, black vinegar.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And especially if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not apply cerates or anything that contains oil to the wound, so as not to cause putrefaction and decay.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then administer a splint at the hour when your restoration of the bone is complete.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And leave the wound exposed: cut openings with scissors in the bandages according to the size of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And be careful at all times not to bind the wound tightly with a fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For often foolish physicians have done this: and it has happened that they caused either death or corruption or gangrene, that is, putrefaction, to come upon their patients.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And let your dressing be soft, gentle, different from the dressings of other fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	If the wound is bad or the wound is large, and you fear some of the harmful accidents that we have mentioned may occur, and you feel pain in a suspended area: then you should not place a splint over it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make bandages from hard cloth in place of splints, and bind them tightly with these.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	However, after one day or two days, and you see the wound beginning to generate pus: then remove the cloth that you placed over it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply licorice, and ointments that we customarily use to treat wounds: such as the tetrapharmakon ointment, and similar ones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	It is appropriate for you to loosen the bandage.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And examine the wound every day in the morning and evening until it is healed and has consolidated.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And it is necessary to prepare the limb in such a way that the pus can run from it to the lower parts with ease.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If many days pass for the wound and it does not heal, nor is the pus expelled from it: then you should know that there are small fractures of the bone inside.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	Therefore, it is necessary to examine the wound with probes.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	However, of those parts that are separated by alsatagi, remove them and extract them.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And those of them that are not separated and sting the limb and cause pain, try to cut them and remove them in every way possible for you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If it happens that the wound becomes zuchen, or ekilet, that is, estiomenum, or some other form of corruption and putrefaction: then it is necessary to apply to each one of them what is appropriate for its treatment, as was previously described in its chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from the point where my speech must stand, and to which you should give your full attention when a bone is broken and protrudes above the limb, such as the hip bone or the shoulder bone, and similar large bones: do not attempt to pull it out, for often death results from that; rather, leave it alone until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps it will fall out on its own after twenty days or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then care for the wound if you deem it necessary: and if not, leave it be.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	Regarding the treatment of Nodation in a foot fracture.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	This Nodation often occurs during the healing process of a foot fracture.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially those near the joints: and it disfigures the shape of the limb.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And it may prevent the limb from performing its natural function.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Therefore, if there is recent bleeding, administer medicines that have astringent properties, such as aloes, frankincense, myrrh, stacte, acacia, and similar substances.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Thus, take some of these or all of them and mix them with astringent wine, or with egg white, or with vinegar. Then apply them to the bleeding on cotton wool and secure them tightly over it.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And leave the dressing in place without removing it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then remove it and apply another dressing, until the bleeding stops.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind it over a properly placed lead plate.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead has the property of removing anything that is feared from the limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the clot has already turned to a hardened mass and is firmly attached, and urgent necessity requires its removal: then apply a bandage above it, and cut away any protruding excess. Or scrape it with some scrapers until it is removed, and take care of it until it heals.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	Regarding the treatment when the limb is restored but remains thin, not as it should be by nature.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When a bone fracture is restored but the limb remains thin and weak, this happens for many reasons.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	One reason is the excessive cutting and binding of the ligaments not as it should be, or due to excess constriction of the ligaments, preventing nourishment from reaching the limb. Another reason is an abundance of unnecessary embrocations at the wrong time, or a lack of blood in the patient's body and their general weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And the treatment for that is to feed the sick person and make his body soft until the blood multiplies within him.
Et administra balneum.	And administer a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and happiness to him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then apply pitch to the limb: so that the pitch attracts abundant nourishment to it.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And let him have an embrocation with warm water until the nourishment circulates and returns to its natural form.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	Regarding the treatment of broken bones when they heal crookedly.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When it happens that a limb, already healed after its injury, becomes crooked, and the broken bone protrudes or forms a knot: and this disfigures the shape of the limb, although the limb is not prevented from performing its natural function: then you should not heed the advice of those who suggest that the limb be broken again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there have already been many foolish physicians and healers who have done this in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And this operation is indeed very disgraceful, leading to death or great fear, as it may be fatal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	However, if the limping and knotting are recent: then it is necessary to embrocate with warm water in which softening herbs have been decocted, such as the leaves of mallows, and its root, and melilotus, and similar herbs.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And prepare an ointment with a softening plaster, such as properly prepared mastic resin ointment.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Take the mucilage of the root of flax, and mix it with chicken fat or sesame oil; and apply it as a plaster.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Take soft figs and pound them with dove's fat, and similar substances that are called medicine reducing consolidation.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And sometimes the knot is loosened with constant, old-fashioned, and gentle friction, which is done with wet hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And administer movement of the limb to all parts at all times.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	But if the curvature has already preceded and become hard, and turned into stone, and necessity has arisen to treat it with iron: then it is necessary to cut above it, and dissolve the continuity of the bone, and cut away what is excessive from the knot or bone with fine cutting instruments: and facilitate this with care and diligence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	Regarding the discussion on Dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the displacement of some joint from its proper place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Therefore, it is prohibited from its movement and disfigures the shape of the member.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes pain and severe injuries to occur to the patient.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When therefore a dislocation occurs to someone, it is necessary to hurry to restore it: do not delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the area will become infected, and perhaps along with it, the reduction of the dislocation will be hindered.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore, it should not be moved nor extended during the hour of its abscess.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For it often causes spasms and painful injuries.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when that happens, then it is necessary to hurry with the bloodletting of the patient.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then let it be left alone until the abscess subsides.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb should be treated with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it should be reduced gently.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And the entire limb should be treated along with the part that will be mentioned in its place.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have already organized the chapters on dislocations, even as they precede fractures, from the upper part of the body to the lower.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	¶ On the treatment of the dislocation of the lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two jaws are rarely dislocated to a great extent.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both occurs in one of two ways.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Either they are slightly moved from their places and then relaxed for a short while.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are dislocated completely, until they relax towards the chest area, until saliva flows from the patient and they cannot hold it back, and their tongue gets entangled with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When, however, the displacement is slight, then it returns to its proper position by itself with little effort.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If it is a complete displacement: then it must be that the reduction is administered quickly, and there should be no delay. The assistant should hold the patient's head, and the physician should insert his thumb of one hand into the root of the jaw at the side of the mouth, if the displacement is on one side.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he should insert two thumbs simultaneously if the displacement is on both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of his hands should be outside, with which he will stabilize.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And instruct the patient to open his jaws and move them in all directions for chewing.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician should stabilize the jaw and move it until it returns to its proper place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If the reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are displaced simultaneously: then administer steam with warm water and oil until the reduction of both becomes easy. Do not delay the reduction of both, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they return and are stabilized, and the patient's mouth closes without softening: then place bandages covered with wax made of beeswax and rose oil over them.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then bind it gently with soft bands.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the patient sleep on his back: and place his head between two pillows so that he does not move it to the right or left: nor should he attempt, or be forced, to chew anything: instead, give him a light broth until the pain subsides and the jaw heals: then he may eat what he wants, but do so gently.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	Do not work on the operation of his mouth during eating and drinking, and kissing, until the jaw is stabilized and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of both jaws becomes difficult when they are dislocated at some hour and do not return to their places, then often fevers and continuous sweating occur; and perhaps the patient's belly is loosened, and he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see that happening, then know it is a loss, and often the one to whom it happens dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	Concerning the reduction of the dislocation of the collarbone and the end of the shoulder.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The collarbone does not dislocate from the inner side due to its connection with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it can dislocate outward at times, and this is apparent to the senses.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is such that the patient should lie on their back and extend their arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then compress the area with your strong hand, for it will return to its place.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then apply a plaster and bandages, and bind it tightly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	However, the parts that follow the elbow and are connected to it do not dislocate, except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	When it dislocates on some day, then it is necessary to reduce and align it as we have said, and as you have prepared.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place the plaster, and the powders, and the bandage over it.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the patient to adhere to calmness and rest until healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same treatment, the shoulder joint is reduced when it has become dislocated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	Concerning the reduction of a dislocated shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the shoulder does not become dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is that it becomes dislocated towards the front to the lower part.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is that it becomes dislocated toward the side of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it may become dislocated toward the upper part of the shoulder: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it does not become dislocated towards the back, due to the scapula.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not become dislocated toward the front, due to the nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And it dislocates and exits towards the front to the lower part most often, especially in those whose muscles are thin.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it exits quickly and enters back quickly in them.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	In those whose muscles are thick, it is the opposite; that is, because it exits with difficulty and enters with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And sometimes it happens that a blow or fall occurs, and the shoulder becomes inflamed with a hot abscess, and it is thought because of this that it has already become dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore, you should test it until you stand on its certainty, and then proceed with its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	A dislocation is recognized when it is directed downwards towards the joint: and you must distinguish between a dislocated shoulder and a healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find a clear difference between them, and you will discover a concavity in the head of the shoulder, and below the joint, upon touching the head of the shoulder, it seems as if it were an egg: and the injured person cannot bring their hand to their ear or move it in any way.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	And similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upwards: then you will find a clear touch, and it is not hidden.
